column1: Prescott ( PRESS-kət) is a city in Yavapai County
column3: United States. According to the 2010 Census
column4: the population of the city is 39
column5: 843. The city is the county seat of Yavapai County. In 1864
column6: Prescott was designated as the capital of the Arizona Territory
column7: replacing the temporary capital at Fort Whipple. The Territorial Capital was moved to Tucson in 1867. Prescott again became the Territorial Capital in 1877
column8: until Phoenix became the capital in 1889.

column1: The Yavapai-Prescott Indian Tribe reservation is located adjacent to and partially within the borders of Prescott.
Prescott is in the Granite Creek watershed and contains the convergence of Miller Creek and Granite Creek on its north side.
Arizona Territorial Governor John Noble Goodwin selected the original site of Prescott following his first tour of the new territory. Goodwin replaced Governor John A. Gurley
column3: who died before taking office. Downtown streets in Prescott are named in honor of each of them. Goodwin selected a site 20 miles (32 km) south of the temporary capital on the east side of Granite Creek near a number of mining camps. The territorial capital was later moved to the new site along with Fort Whipple
column4: with the new town named in honor of historian William H. Prescott during a public meeting on May 30
column5: 1864. Robert W. Groom surveyed the new community
column6: and an initial auction sold 73 lots on June 4
column9: a total of 232 lots had been sold within the new community. Prescott was officially incorporated in 1881.Prescott served as capital of Arizona Territory until November 1
column11: when the capital was moved to Tucson by act of the 4th Arizona Territorial Legislature. The capital was returned to Prescott in 1877 by the 9th Arizona Territorial Legislature. The capital was finally moved to Phoenix on February 4
column13: by the 15th Arizona Territorial Legislature. The three Arizona Territory capitals reflected the changes in political influence of different regions of the territory as they grew and developed.

column1: Prescott also holds a place in the larger history of the American southwest. Both Virgil Earp (brother of Wyatt Earp) and Doc Holliday lived in Prescott before their now infamous gunfight at the O.K. Corral. Virgil Earp lived in Prescott starting in 1878 as a constable/watchman. Doc Holliday was there for a while in the summer of 1880 and even appears in the 1880 census records.The Sharlot Hall Museum houses much of Prescott's territorial history
column2: and the Smoki and Phippen museums also maintain local collections. Whiskey Row in downtown Prescott boasts many historic buildings
column3: including The Palace
column4: Arizona's oldest restaurant and bar is still the oldest frontier saloon in Arizona. Many other buildings that have been converted to boutiques
column7: and restaurants. Prescott is home to the Arizona Pioneers' Home. The Home opened during territorial days

column3: a lawn under huge old elm trees
column4: is a gathering and meeting place. Cultural events and performances take place on many nights in the summer on the plaza.

column1: Prescott is considered part of North Central Arizona. It is just south of the Granite Dells. The Granite Dells area
column3: is known for its large boulder outcroppings of granite that have eroded into a spectacular appearance of bumpy rock features. Within 'The Dells' are Watson and Willow Lakes
column5: man-made reservoirs. Here a number of hiking trails connect to the Peavine Trail. The Peavine National Recreation Trail follows what was the former rail bed of the Santa Fe. This railroad traveled from Prescott to Phoenix through the Granite Dells. The "Peavine" got its name from the winding portion of this railroad that twists and curves
column6: resembling the vine on which peas grow. The Peavine trail connects to the Iron King Trail
column7: which was the route of the old Prescott Railroad through the Granite Dells. Natural lakes include Lynx
column9: all surrounding different areas of this rustic community. Goldwater Lake
column11: is 4 miles (6.4 km) from downtown Prescott
column12: has 15 acres (6.1 ha) of water surface
column13: and is a popular destination for park recreation and picnic facilities. Lynx Lake is another lake close to Prescott in tall ponderosa pines
column15: 000 visitors every year. This 55-acre (22 ha) lake offers visitors recreational activities
column22: seasonal restaurant with a view of the lake. Finally
column23: there is the smallest of the natural lakes with 5 acres (2.0 ha) of surface water at Granite Basin Lake. None of these lakes permits swimming due to a history of water quality problems
column24: however all are popular recreational destinations near Prescott.

column1: Prescott is in the Bradshaw Mountains of central Arizona
column3: 400 feet (1
column4: 600 m). The city has a Mediterranean climate (Köppen Csa); however
column5: unlike most other locations in this climate class
column6: there is a pronounced summer wet season due to the North American Monsoon.

column1: Average annual precipitation for 1981–2010 was 17.75 inches (451 mm)
column2: with spring and early summer the driest times of the year. Snowfall is typically light and snow cover usually melts away quickly; the 1981–2011 average seasonal total was 12.8 inches (33 cm).The largest portion of precipitation falls during the July–September monsoon season. Average daytime temperatures remain above 50 °F (10 °C) the entire year
column3: but diurnal temperature variation is large throughout the year
column6: though 100 °F (38 °C)+ readings are uncommon and do not occur every year
column7: much unlike the Sonoran Desert to the south and Mojave Desert to the west. The average season for freezing temperatures is October 21 through May 1.There was a severe drought from 1999 to 2009
column8: seen from the lack of snowpack in the Bradshaw Mountains. Local creeks do not contain water except immediately after the rare rains. Nevertheless
column9: at the start of 2007 lakes were reported as full. The winter of 2005–06 had less than 3 inches (7.6 cm) of snow
column10: compared to an average snowfall of 12.8 inches (33 cm).

column1: Prescott is affected each year by the North American Monsoon. Monsoon season is June 15–Sept. 15
column3: wind
column6: and flooding to the area. In spite of the dangers of flash floods and wildfires
column7: many locals enjoy monsoon season for the relief of cooler temperatures
column8: which commonly result from storms during the height of summer heatwaves.Arizona receives half of its annual rainfall during monsoon season
column9: but this can be misleading. Monthly averages in precipitation can give the false impression that rains are confined to monsoon season
column10: while single-day annual rainfall records have been set far outside of monsoon season
column11: repeatedly. The area is prone to weather extremes and often
column12: monthly rainfall records are actually the result of one or two dramatic rain events.

column1: Prescott area residents have faced the challenges of extreme rain and flash flooding since the first prospectors arrived in search of gold in the late 1800s. In 1863 Joseph R. Walker's original mining camp on the banks of Lynx Creek was completely swept away in a flash flood less than a year after arriving in Prescott. In the late 1880s
column2: floods destroyed the first dam on Lynx creek near present-day SR-69. 1891 brought the heaviest flooding on record across Arizona (a record broken in 1993)
column3: carving lasting changes to the Verde river drainage
column5: which has in some years been completely dry
column7: 284 cubic meters per second of water on Feb 24
column9: or about half the size of the Columbia river.Tropical Storm Octave
column11: brought 14.5" of rain to parts of Prescott in less than forty-eight hours. Damages included the Santa Fe Railway
column12: which was washed out in so many places it was completely abandoned the following year. Two Prescott area college students died in Granite Creek during flooding in 2004
column13: which brought an official state of emergency declaration from state governor Napolitano. Significant flooding has been recorded as recently as 2018
column14: prompting the evacuation of nearby Mayer in August.A large number of homes in Prescott are located within FEMA designated "high risk flood zones A and AE". The City of Prescott recently updated Flood Insurance Rate Maps in response to increased construction and notable flooding for several consecutive years.

column1: The Prescott Gateway Mall is an enclosed shopping mall that opened in 2002
column3: which was Prescott's first enclosed mall when it opened in 1980.Downtown Prescott has dozens of independently owned and operated shops.

column1: Prescott has many Victorian style homes. Prescott has 809 buildings on the National Register of Historic Places. The tallest house in North America
column2: Falcon Nest is located in Prescott
column3: on the slope of Thumb Butte.

column1: Prescott is home to the downtown historical area known as Whiskey Row. Adjacent to Whiskey Row
column3: which operated until 1917
column4: at which point prostitution was outlawed in the state of Arizona. In 1900
column5: a great fire destroyed almost all of the buildings on Whiskey Row
column7: advertised as "the only absolutely fireproof building in Prescott". By legend
column8: the patrons of the various bars simply took their drinks across the street to the Courthouse square and watched it burn. At the time of the fire
column9: the entire bar and back-bar of the Palace Restaurant & Saloon was removed to the square by the patrons as the fire approached
column10: re-installing it after the gutted brick structure was rebuilt. Whiskey Row runs north and south on Montezuma St. between Gurley and Goodwin St.
column11: directly west of the county courthouse. This single city block has been the home of the St. Michael's Hotel (formerly the Hotel Burke) and the Palace Hotel since the late 19th century
column12: along with other colorful purveyors of night-life. Originally built in 1877
column13: The Palace Restaurant and Saloon was rebuilt after the fire
column14: and is now the oldest continuous business in the entire state. Merchant Sam Hill's large hardware store was located near Whiskey Row.There are four golf courses within the city limits: Antelope Hills Golf Course
column15: which consist of the City of Prescott South Course and the City of Prescott North Course
column16: Capital Canyon Golf Club (formerly the Hassayampa Golf Club) (private)
column18: and Prescott Lakes Golf Club (private). More public courses are located nearby in surrounding towns.Prescott is home to The Arizona Pioneers' Home
column20: operated and funded by the State of Arizona
column21: originally intended for impoverished Arizona founders from Territorial days. Initially the home was built to house 40 men
column22: but in 1916 an addition of a women's wing was completed to provide for 20 women. Later
column24: the home again expanded to include Arizona's Hospital for Disabled Miners (current total capacity is 150 beds). Scenes from the 2008 movie Jolene were filmed in the Pioneer's Home in 2006. The Home has had many colorful residents
column26: who had claimed to be Billy the Kid
column27: and who was exhumed from the Pioneer's Home Cemetery in 2005 in an attempt to identify DNA evidence. Another resident was "Big Nose Kate" Elder
column28: who would also be laid to rest in the Pioneer's Home Cemetery
column29: though not without controversy.Prescott is home to Prescott College
column30: a small liberal arts college located just west of the downtown area that emphasizes environmental and social justice. It is a non-profit organization which has an undergraduate body of roughly 800 students
column31: and an average student to faculty ratio of 7:1 in on-campus classrooms. There are four general programs at Prescott College: the On-campus Undergraduate Program (RDP)
column33: the Limited-Residency Master of Arts Program (MAP)
column34: and a Limited-Residency PhD program in Sustainability Education. Those enrolled in the Limited-Residency programs work with various mentors and Prescott College faculty
column35: usually in their home communities. On-campus students live in Prescott and attend classes at the college itself.

column1: Prescott was at one point a recovery destination
column2: with over 200 sober living homes dedicated to drug or alcohol recovery. However
column3: increased regulation and enforcement has whittled that number down to less than 30 as of June 2018.The cultures of Prescott's recovery community
column5: and preexisting small town punk subculture have fostered a thriving punk scene. Shows are hosted weekly at house venues
column7: and bars throughout downtown and the Dexter neighborhood. Prescott has been home to several nationally known punk bands
column10: and Hour of the Wolf. Local bands often play shows alongside touring bands
column11: who include Prescott in their tours.Prescott hosts annual events such as Frontier Days
column12: The World's Oldest Rodeo (1888) (featured in the 1972 film Junior Bonner)
column22: World's Largest Gingerbread Village at the Prescott Resort & Conference center (located on the Yavapai-Prescott Indian Tribe reservation)
column30: Whiskey Off Road and Ragnar Relay Del Sol. On New Year's Eve
column31: historic Whiskey Row saw the inaugural Prescott Boot Drop to usher in the 2012 New Year. The illuminated 6-foot (1.8 m) tall cowboy boot with multi-colored stars was lowered from the historic Palace Restaurant rooftop's 40-foot (12 m) flagpole to the delight and cheers of celebrants gathered on Montezuma Street which was closed for the occasion. Also located in Prescott is the Heritage Park Zoo.Prescott was the location of Arizona's first Elks Lodge (BPOE). In December 1895 a group of enterprising businessmen in Prescott established the Prescott Elks Lodge #330
column32: known as the "Mother Lodge of Arizona". The Prescott Elks Opera House was built by the lodge in 1905. The Prescott Elks Lodge is currently located in Prescott Valley.

column1: Prescott was designated "Arizona's Christmas City" by Arizona Governor Rose Mofford in 1989.
2000: Downtown Historic Preservation District (which includes "Whiskey Row") – one of 12 such National Register Historic Districts within the city.
2004: A "Preserve American Community" in 2004 by First Lady Laura Bush.
2006: One of a "Dozen Distinctive Destinations" by the National Trust for Historic Preservation.
2008: Yavapai Courthouse Plaza recognized as one of the first ten "Great Public Places" in America by the American Planning Association.
2012: Number 1 True Western Town of the Year for 2011 by True West Magazine and One of the 61 Best Old House Neighborhoods in the U.S and Canada by This Old House Magazine.
The City of Prescott operates under a council-manager form of government. The council has six council members and a mayor
column2: all elected at-large by the people of Prescott. Council members are elected to staggered four-year terms
column3: and the mayor to a two-year term. Elections for mayor and council members are held in the first year after the national presidential and mid-term elections to keep national issues from overshadowing local concerns. Mayoral and council elections are non-partisan. There are no term limits for council members or the mayor. The council appoints a professional city manager to oversee the daily administrative operations of city services and their respective departments
column4: including the Prescott Fire Department. The current city manager is Michael Lamar. The current mayor is Greg L. Mengarelli

column1: Granite Mountain Middle School (serves 5th and 6th grades)
Mile High Middle School (serves 7th and 8th grades)
Pre-School (A district preschool has been operating in the Washington Elementary since the latter's closure in 2015)
Tri-City College Prep High SchoolPrescott Unified School District operates public schools. There are 18 public schools
column3: in grades K-12 and four private schools in Prescott. In 2015
column5: the Prescott Unified School District closed Washington Elementary and Miller Valley Elementary schools. To make up for the change all elementary schools only went up to 4th grade. Granite Mountain Middle School serves 5th and 6th grades. Mile High Middle School serves 7th and 8th grades and Prescott High School remains unchanged.  A district preschool has been operating in the Washington Elementary since the latter's closure.  A recent renovation of the building will be completed in 2018 and will also be the home of the Prescott Unified School District Offices.

column1: Other private companies provide airport shuttles to Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport.The three main thoroughfares in and around Prescott are Arizona State Route 89A
column2: Arizona State Route 69 and Arizona State Route 89. State Route 89A connects Sedona and Cottonwood to Northern Prescott and meets with State Route 89 near the Airport eventually turning into Pioneer Parkway where it connects to Williamson Valley Road. State Route 69 connects Prescott with Prescott Valley to the east
column3: eventually curving southeast before reaching Interstate 17 at mile marker 262
column4: about 65 miles (105 km) from downtown Phoenix. State Route 89 travels mostly north–south and connects Prescott with Chino Valley and Paulden to the north
column5: continuing northward until it joins Interstate 40 at mile marker 146

column1: In 2016 ADOT realigned willow creek road in between State Route 89 and Pioneer Parkway adding a round about on State Route 89 with new access to the Ernest A. Love Field Airport. A future Great western Corridor is planned go on the east side of the Ernest A. Love Field Airport and provide an alternative route to the Airport.
